title: 104_s1206
content: The "Adoption Assistance Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces a refundable credit for adoption expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income. The Adoption Assistance Act provides a credit for qualified adoption expenses, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income, with specific limitations on expenses and double benefits. The Adoption Assistance Act allows for a credit for qualified adoption expenses, such as adoption fees, court costs, and attorney fees, directly related to the legal adoption of a child by the taxpayer. Expenses for the adoption of a spouse's child are not eligible. Married couples must file joint returns for this credit. The Adoption Assistance Act allows for a credit for qualified adoption expenses, such as adoption fees, court costs, and attorney fees. Section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include section 35. Amendments are also made to the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act allows for a credit for qualified adoption expenses. Section 35 addresses adoption expenses, while Section 36 deals with overpayments of tax. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. Additionally, Title II focuses on adoption assistance for federal employees, specifically reimbursement for adoption expenses under Subpart G of part III of title 5, United States Code. In Chapter 90, adoption benefits are outlined, defining terms like 'agency' and 'employee'. Adoption expenses include fees charged by adoption agencies. The regulations outline various adoption expenses that may be reimbursed, including fees charged by adoption agencies, placement fees, legal fees, counseling fees, medical expenses, foster-care charges, and transportation expenses. Additionally, employees of adoption agencies may be reimbursed for adoption expenses incurred after the adoption becomes final. Reimbursement for adoption expenses under this section is determined by the laws of the jurisdiction governing the adoption. It is payable if the child is under 18 years old, unmarried, and an appropriate written application is filed. The reimbursement may not exceed $2,000 and is only provided if other similar benefits do not cover the full amount of adoption expenses. The reimbursement for adoption expenses is determined by the laws of the jurisdiction governing the adoption and may not exceed $2,000. If both adopting parents are eligible for reimbursement, each parent can receive an amount determined in accordance with the guidelines. No payment shall exceed the total adoption expenses incurred or $4,000. Guidelines issued under subsection (g) will include provisions for interagency cooperation. Any amount payable will be paid from the designated fund. The Office of Personnel Management may issue guidelines for uniform administration of reimbursement for adoption expenses, which will be paid from the designated fund. The regulations by Executive agencies must align with these guidelines. The Office can provide assistance to agencies upon request for implementing this section. The text discusses the amendment of section 1005 of title 39, United States Code, to apply section 9001 of title 5 to the Postal Service. Regulations must align with guidelines issued under subsection (g)(1) of such section. The effective date of these changes is also mentioned. The text discusses the effective date of a title related to adoption assistance, which will be in effect from October 1, 1995. It applies to adoptions finalized after that date. The amendment includes the exclusion of adoption assistance in the Internal Revenue Code. The text discusses the exclusion of employee adoption assistance benefits and military adoption assistance benefits from an employee's gross income. Employee adoption assistance benefits cover qualified adoption expenses paid by the employer, while military adoption assistance benefits are benefits provided to military personnel for adoption. The term 'military adoption assistance benefits' refers to benefits provided under specific sections of the United States Code for the legal adoption of an eligible child by military personnel. Qualified adoption expenses include reasonable fees directly related to the adoption process and not in violation of any laws. The Secretary will issue regulations to coordinate the application of this section with other provisions allowing a credit or deduction for qualified adoption expenses. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. Effective Date: The amendments made in this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
